awd_titl_txt: Forming Collective Memories:  From local influences to global mnemonic convergence
awd_abstract_narration:
The present research explores how collective memories are formed, maintained, changed, and forgotten.  How do collective  memories form? To a large extent, the formation of collective memories occurs through acts of communication.  One person might talk to another person about a past event, or one person might watch a video about an event on the Internet. Eventually, some of these memories are propagated throughout the group. The present research examines how acts of person-to-person communication can establish, strengthen, change and weaken what people remember of their own and others' collective past.  It tests the mechanisms by which this interpersonal influence can spread across a network, affect the memories of those with whom there is no direct connection, and in so doing, have a marked effect on the collective memory formed across the network. 

Three sets of experiments are proposed. Using a modified version of the serial reproduction task, the first set examines the extent to which the three conversational influences of interest - reinforcement, induced forgetting, and the implantation of memories - spread across transmission chains of various sizes. It tests whether the extent of this propagation is a function of the strength of these conversational influences and whether these strengths, in turn, are a function of social relationships and the medium of communication. The second phase explores mnemonic convergence, that is, the extent to which a chain of individuals converges onto the same shared memories. Specifically, it investigates whether the extent of propagation can not exceed the length of the transmission chain if convergence is to occur. The third phase moves beyond transmission chains to complex social networks. It now probes for the degree to which mnemonic convergence is a function of both the extent of propagation, or in turn, the strength of conversational influences, and the average length between all pairings of individuals in the network. It also introduces cluster coefficients as an additional variable of interest. The proposed research brings together for the first time two strands of relevant research:  the burgeoning experimentally-based psychological literature on the effect of communication on memory in dyads and the widely discussed work on the propagation of influence through social networks. This synergistic approach produces a model with great general applicability, particularly in the domain of national security. Its interdisciplinarity will link psychological research on individual memory with work on networks and social connectedness. As a result, graduate students working on the proposed research will receive a unique training.  Overall, the proposed research provides an empirical foundation for a model of collective memory formation that will impact on societally important issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Collective memories, that is, memories shared across a group, can ground a group's identity and shape a group's actions.  They are often linked to a host of social benefits – national pride, for instance – and social problems – for instance, intergroup conflict.  The sponsored research examined the psychological processes underlying the formation and maintenance of collective memories, with an emphasis on the consequences of the silences that often permeate public discourse.  Such selective remembering can take place in one-way conversations (as between politicians and their audience), two-way conversations (as among friends about a rock band they all like), or sequences of conversational exchanges (as among fellow students about an instructors' grading policy).  A politician, for instance, might emphasize some facts, while neglecting to mention other, or a group of friends might stress the good things they know about the band and be silent about the bad things.  In both laboratory and survey work, the sponsored research explored how such selective remembering can lead to selective forgetting, with the public less likely to remember what the politician left unsaid and the group of friends less likely to remember the bad things about the rock group.  Critically, the research underscored that such forgetting is not simply a matter of decay.  To be sure, if a memory goes unmentioned, it will decay over time.  But the rate of forgetting is greater when people leave that memory talking about material related to the unmentioned memory.  That is, selective remembering comes at a cost.  It induced and enhances selective forgetting, for both speaker and listener.

 

            The sponsored research demonstrated that such selective forgetting can be long-lasting, thereby providing conditions that might lead to the formation of a lasting collective memory built around, in part, selectively forgotten material.  Moreover, it is more likely to occur when speaker and listener belong to the same social group.  The research specifically examined differences across pre-existing groups, such as racial groups.  It also investigated the consequences of silence in real world setting, examining, for instance, the effect of the King of Belgium's speech to the Belgian public.  Those who listened to the speech had worse memory for topics the King talked about than those who failed to listen to the speech.  Finally, it examined the limits on the extent to which a speaker's mnemonic influence can propagate through a social network.  A mathematical model of mechanisms of this propagation suggests that collective memory formation is enhanced by multiple conversations, but only up to a point, after which subsequent conversations have little effect.

 

            Overall, the sponsored research furthers our understanding of how basic psychological processes can promote the formation of collective memory.  It suggests that human memory is well-adapted to promote the formation of collective memory.  In underscoring this point, it provides a means of understanding how psychology can help unravel the effectiveness, or the lack of effectiveness, of the social practices designed to promote the formation and maintenance of collective memory and why some collective memories persist over time and others fade.
